title: Supreme Court temporarily blocks $6 billion Purdue Pharma-Sackler bankruptcy
description: Supreme Court's decision to review the controversial bankruptcy deal involving the maker of Oxycontin means the settlement will remain on hold at least through December.

title: San Francisco has lots of self-driving cars. They're driving first responders nuts
description: It's hard to miss self-driving cars and their rooftop sensors in San Francisco. But now they're facing unexpected resistance from the city's police and fire departments.

title: How much should a mother divulge to her daughters? Ann Patchett weighs it up
description: In the new novel Tom Lake, a mother bonds with her daughters who are home for the pandemic. But how much of her past is she expected to share?

title: Here's where inflation stands today — and why it's raising hope about the economy
description: Consumer prices rose 3.2% in July from a year ago, higher than the 3% gain seen in June — but it was largely due to math. Overall, inflation continues to ease, raising optimism about the economy.

title: The Biden administration is seeking billions in additional funding for Ukraine
description: The funding request for Ukraine could set up a showdown with Congress, where far-right Republicans as well as the left of the Democratic Party are skeptical of additional funding for the conflict.

title: Atlantic hurricane season is now predicted to be 'above-normal' this year, NOAA says
description: The Atlantic hurricane season is now projected to have "above-normal level of activity" according to an updated forecast from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Special counsel proposes a trial date for Trump Jan. 6 case
description: The special counsel's office has proposed that a federal judge set Jan. 2, 2024 as the start of former President Donald Trump's trial on charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

title: A writer pieces together the story of a family secret: An aunt who was sent away
description: In an Atlantic article, "The Ones We Sent Away," Jennifer Senior tells the story of her aunt, who was institutionalized at age 21 months because of her intellectual and developmental disability.

title: More endangered red wolves will be released in the U.S. under a legal settlement
description: There were only an estimated seven red wolves left in the wild when a coalition of conservation organizations decided to sue the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Iran has moved some American prisoners to house arrest — a step to possible release
description: The move raises prospects of a prisoner swap, and comes amid months of diplomacy between Europe, the U.S. and Iran via mediators.

title: Inside Russia's attempts to hack Ukrainian military operations
description: Ukrainian officials say Russian hackers remain focused on infiltrating military planning operations. That includes seizing and trying to crack tablets used on the on the front lines by officers.

title: Thomas accepted more gifts from billionaire benefactors, new ProPublica report says
description: The conservative justice took at least 38 vacations, 26 private jet flights, eight flights by helicopter, a dozen VIP passes to sporting events and stays at luxury resorts, according to ProPublica.

title: Emmy Awards rescheduled to Jan. 15 due to Hollywood strikes
description: The 75th Emmy Awards have been rescheduled to broadcast on Monday, Jan. 15, 2024 — Martin Luther King Jr. Day. It's television's most prestigious awards show, but ratings have been dropping steadily.

title: Getting clear prices for hospital care could get easier under a proposed rule
description: The Biden administration wants hospitals to do more to make their prices understandable, so that consumers know in advance what a health care service will cost them.

title: Inflation got a little higher in July as prices for rent and gas spiked
description: Consumer prices rose 3.2% in July from a year ago, up slightly from the 3% annual rise see in June — but still within analyst expectations

title: Up First briefing: Wildfires ravage Maui; meet the Women's World Cup quarterfinalists
description: Deadly wildfires tear across the Hawaiian island of Maui. Spain and the Netherlands kick off the Women's World Cup quarterfinals tonight.

title: How heat makes health inequity worse, hitting people with risks like diabetes harder
description: Heat is dangerous for the many people with common conditions like diabetes or heart disease. And vulnerable communities face greater exposure to heat and fewer resources to escape it.

title: After decades, a tribe's vision for a new marine sanctuary could be coming true
description: The Biden administration is moving ahead with what could be the largest national marine sanctuary in the continental U.S. A Native American tribe is hoping to be partners in managing it.

title: Hollywood strikes' economic impacts are hitting far beyond LA
description: The writers and actors strikes in Hollywood are affecting jobs across the U.S. The Motion Picture Association says film and TV productions employ more than 1.7 million people outside California.

title: In California, wildfires are prevented by crews of unlikely firefighters: goats
description: The four-legged creatures with digestive tracts of steel make easy work of consuming vegetation that typically fuels wildfires.

title: Pakistan's parliament is dissolved to pave way for elections
description: Pakistan's president on Wednesday dissolved the lower house of parliament as the country's top opposition leader is fighting to overturn a corruption conviction.

title: A presidential candidate in Ecuador has been shot and killed at campaign event
description: Fernando Villavicencio was shot and killed Wednesday by an unidentified gunman while at a political rally in the country's capital of Quito, President Guillermo Lasso said.

title: Six takeaways from Disney's quarterly earnings call
description: In a fickle media market, Disney's overall revenue grew 4%. Despite declining ad revenue and uncertainty over the Hollywood writers and actors strikes, CEO Bob Iger sees growth opportunities.
